oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Definition of Benefit-Risk Relationships Associated with Drug Usage in Veterinary Medicine
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Aronson, Arthur L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: dosage recommendation
therapeutic drug use
benefit-risk
drug usage
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: There are many issues relating to drug usage in veterinary medicine that could be considered under the general heading of benefit-risk relationships. I shall consider one issue that increasingly has been brought to my attention in my capacity of teaching pharmacology. This issue involves interpretation of some package inserts for veterinary drugs. The dosage recommendations may not be compatible with what is considered to be consistent with optimal therapeutic use of the drug. For example, it is recommended that ampicillin be dosed once daily (s.i.d.) in calves. In contrast, it is recommended that ampicillin be dosed four times daily (q.i.d.) in package inserts for human use. The serum half-life is approximately 90 minutes in both species. The veterinarian who wishes to use the drug optimally would be going beyond the package insert recommendations and thus may be personally liable for any adverse consequences.
